climbs.name: Young Tree
climbs.fa: Dino Banco/ Frank Bentwood/ Kelly Vaught.

content.description: Just to the right of Global Revolution. Climb up the left side of a large shelf. Clip a bolt then do an awkward mantel on to the shelf. Clip the bolt to your right and keep moving right around the corner to a good stance. Lay back up then right to get you on to the shelf and the start of the crux on excellent rock.
content.protection: 8 bolts/anchors.
content.location: Last bolted route on the cliff line.

climbs.name: Way of Life
climbs.fa: Paul Turecki, Ivo Ninov and Dave Griffith

content.description:
Climb up 5.7 ramp to six bolts that traverse out right for 30 ft.  Straight forward movements until the end, beware of loose blocks and grit. Distinctly uncharacteristic of Joshua Tree climbing, worth doing.

A slightly harder variation can be done at the last bolt.
content.protection: One or two hand sized pieces, 6 bolts. Two bolt anchor with tat and leaver biners.
content.location: Located on the far left end of the North face of Snickers, obvious large corner/roof system.

climbs.name: Ulnar Nerve
climbs.fa: Todd & Donette Swain, George Hurley, 2009

content.description:
This three bolt variation to Funny Bone starts about 20' to the left of that route.  Climb past three bolts, with an optional small cam between the first and second bolts.  Continue on to Funny Bone about 1/4 of the way up that route (another possible exit to the left).

Still a bit scrappy, but could be a worthwhile diversion on a warm day.
content.protection: 3 bolts, light rack.  Finish on anchor above Humorous.
content.location: Start just below a tree, 20' to the left of Funny Bone.

climbs.name: Ulna
climbs.fa: FRA: Todd & Donette Swain, George Hurley 2009

content.description:
Start about eight feet left of

Funny Bone

at an obvious, vertical seam/corner. Climb up along the somewhat gritty fissure to the large ledge at mid-height. Finish as for

Funny Bone

.

Rappel with one rope from the anchor atop

Humerus

. The route can be top roped from that anchor.
content.protection: Standard JT rack.
content.location:
Start about eight feet left of

Funny Bone

at an obvious, vertical seam/corner.

climbs.name: Trauma Traverse
climbs.fa: Dino Banco/Erik Wessner, FFA 1st pitch: Erik Wessner 2017

content.description: First pitch is the crux of this route. Clip the first bolt of Young Tree, mantle onto the ledge then go straight up past some tricky 5.10 face climbing past two more bolts that gets you to the start of the traverse. Squeeze into the rest and contemplate eighty feet of straight left traversing. Clip a mix of cams and bolts until you clip the last bolt. Tricky moves into the Alpine Diversions crack (A little run out!) for gear then your looking at the crux. Start at No Place For a Puritan to do the easier last four pitches. climb up the crack about ten feet then start traversing left on the under clings and slab for the feet.
content.protection: Six bolts/Standard rack,gear to #3 .Clip the first bolt of No Place For A Puritan at the end of the first pitch and belay on the ledge or lower to the ground and belay. Pitch two shares Crime Of The Century anchors. Pitch four clips one bolt on Way Of Life and one on Thunderwood. After pitch two its gear anchors for the rest of the route.
content.location: Shares the same start as Young Tree.

climbs.name: Time in the Penitentiary (aka: Two Flew the Coop)
climbs.fa: (TR)  John Bachar, 1978 (1st half  only), FL and upper portion: Tony Sartin & Tom Murphy, April 2007

content.description:
Much like its neighbor to the left, Crime of the Century,

Time in the Penitentiary

start with difficult overhanging moves.  The first technical crux comes early, with a tricky set of moves.  Continue through the upper part of the roof and move left through some flakes to the level of the Crime of the Century anchor. Gear appears as needed, and you'll never get too run out.

From the ledge, clip a pin and set up for the second crux.  A bomber .75 Camalot protects another roof with thin moves.  Moving through juggy patina finishes the 2nd half of the route.
content.protection:
1 bolt, 1 fixed pin, blue alien to yellow Camalot, with doubles from yellow Alien to .75 Camalot.

A heads-up belay is required at the bolt, as blowing the moves just above (the crux) will take you close to the deck. Gear might be possible just after the bolt, but be advised, a placement blew under body weight in this area during the FA efforts.
content.location: Time in the Penitentiary starts 20 right of Crime of the Century.  It is listed in the guidebook as Two Flew the Coop, a Bachar TR.  This route continues higher than the previous TR.

climbs.name: Thunderwood
climbs.fa: Kelly Vaught, Frank Bentwood, Greg Epperson, Tucker Tech, Todd Gordon

content.description:
Starting just below and left of the predominate corner of Norwegian Wood you'll find the base and start of this experience.  Opening moves over green lichen gain you the first bolt in a small right facing corner.   Trending up and slightly left across a sharp dyke system and up through the face crossing over middle banding of this wall.  Bolts are nicely placed with only one section through easier ground that has a larger spacing pattern.   Moving beyond the 4th bolt is undoubtably the crux.  Leader and three other partners were unable to make the move beyond without AO assistance.  Grainy flakes and sketchy rock was not instilling confidence in any of the team.  A short flared hand-crack above leads to the final and probably best moves of the entire route before reaching the bolted anchor.

Rock quality is suspect.  Exfoliating doesn't fully describe the grains and large plates that are ready to detach.  Belayers beware and rocks from above could be headed your way.

Peer pressure and peer pressure alone is rating this route with 1 star.  Length is nice as well as bolt placement but the quality of this line is not desirable.  If you're into grainy ascents thinking it's part of the Joshua Tree experience you may walk away with some satisfaction.
content.protection: 10 quick draws and your preferred bolted anchor set up (runners recommended).  Bolted & chain anchor above.
content.location: Located on the face slightly down & left of Norwiegen Wood.  Most notable by the line of 10 black hangers.

climbs.name: The Ridiculous Finish
climbs.fa: Tony Sartin and Bob Gaines, November 2006

content.description: From the Humerous anchor, this direct finish continues straight up on slightly overhanging face climbing past 2 bolts to the top of the overhanging block, where there is a 2-bolt rappel/lower-off anchor (100 feet).
content.protection: 2 more bolts to a 2-bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Radius
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description:
Start just to the right of

Funny Bone

.

Climb the varnished face between

Funny Bone

and

Humerus

to the mid-height ledge.

This line can be top roped from the

Humerus

anchor.
content.protection: Use the Humerus anchor to TR this climb.
content.location:
Start just to the right of

Funny Bone

.

climbs.name: Norwegian Wood
climbs.fa: Dag Kolsrud, Trond Ornhei & Hank Levine, December 1978

content.description:
This long and varied route, first climbed by a JT local and some visiting Norwegians, starts with a bouldery move onto a ledge and then moves up a right-facing corner with a thin crack that gradually widens as the corner gets steeper. Higher, pass a section with some gritty horizontals (stay left) and continue above in a hand-size crack that turns into an offset fist crack/ow at the top - despite the sound of it good jams can be had in the back and footholds are plentiful making it less of a thrutch than it may seem - the crack narrows at the very top to hands and conludes with a pull onto the level top with a nice view of the desert below.

Gear belay and descend by walking off or making a single rope rap (100') off chain anchors about 40' to the right (above Frankenwood).

This is, for the grade, one of the better crack routes in the area with it's varied moves, good rock and length factored in. Don't forget at least one large cam (4") for the top. Three stars out of five.
content.protection: Gear to 4 inches, including wires

climbs.name: No Place for a Puritan
climbs.fa: Dino Banco

content.description: Climb the easy crack system to a ledge. Clip a bolt and pull  bouldery moves up to a hidden incut hold. Rock quality up to and past the second bolt is not very good but the roof is the reward. Use the crack under the roof to clip the bolt then go. Steep!
content.protection: Possibly gear for the 5.5 crack start then 4 bolts to anchors.
content.location: Walking along the cliff line past Crime Of The Century just before you have to do a down climb look up for this roof route.

climbs.name: Knightshift
climbs.fa: (TR) Bobby Knight, Todd Swain, FL: Tony Sartin, Tom Murphy & Sonja Djuricin, April 2007

content.description:
This was originally done as a TR off of the Crime of the Century midpoint anchor. It now goes to the top of the cliff, joining the Crime of the Century chimney near the top.

Begin 8 feet left of CoC on a juggy, left-trending overhang to a bolt at the lip.

The climb then wanders up the face, paralleling the CoC crack for 80 feet, passing 6 bolts and supplemental gear, to the base of the COC chimney.

Either traverse left and lower off the Humerous anchor or continue up the CoC chimney to the summit. For the most bang for your buck, link this up with the 5.11b Ridiculous Finish.

Crux between 3rd and 4th bolts.

Can be toproped after climbing Humerous or Funnybone.
content.protection: 6 bolts, single set of stoppers, gear from green alien to .75 camalot (larger gear if finishing up the chimney)
content.location: 8 feet left of CoC. Shade all day.

climbs.name: Joyride
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Tony Sartin, May, 2002

content.description:
Begin as per Norwegian Wood, but head up and right on clean looking, greyish rock past 4 bolts (11c) to horizontals. Above continue up gritty rock past 4 more bolts to a 2 bolt anchor; 90 foot rap/lower.

If the upper section of the route gets more traffic (cleans up), it would be a 2 of 3 star (or 3 of 5 star) route. As is 2 of 5 stars.
content.protection: 8 bolts; 2 bolt anchor/90 foot lower/rap. 60 meter rope required!
content.location: This route lies between Norwegian Wood and Frankenwood on the north face of Snickers.

climbs.name: Humerous
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Tony Sartin, May 2002

content.description:
Located on the North Face of Snickers. Begin about 10 feet right of the high point of the base of the rock (10 feet right of Funny Bone and left of Don't Think Just Jump).

Up the face past 2 bolts (10b) then up easy horizontals to an upper face past 2 more bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. The upper section seems a bit contrived, but is OK.
content.protection: 4 bolts, thin to 1 inch pro; 2 bolt anchor/80 foot lower/rap.

climbs.name: Hard Times
climbs.fa: (TR) Bob Gaines and Tony Sartin, May 2002, FL: Dino Banco/Frank Bentwood/Kelly Vaught

content.description: Pulling down on sweet edges past the second bolt is fairly heady then move right on the ever steeping slab clipping bolts to the start of the crux. Layback the ear past 2 bolts clip another bolt off the horizontal holds above the ear then traverse left to the anchors.
content.protection: 7 bolts to anchors.
content.location:
To the right of

No Place for a Puritan

.

climbs.name: Global Revolution
climbs.fa: Dino Banco/ Frank Bentwood/ Kelly Vaught.

content.description: 100 ft. right of hard times find this steep and well protected sport route. A left trending overhanging traverse past two bolts gets you to the business. Thin finger laybacking left trending climbing until your in a corner. Stays pumpy. Excellent rock.
content.protection: 7 bolts/anchors.
content.location: Climb juggy holds straight up to the first bolt then go left.

climbs.name: Funny Bone
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, Steve West, March 1978

content.description: This quality route is almost all on good gray varnish. Interesting moves past thin cracks lead to a ledgy area 1/2 way up. More interesting and steeper moves up thin cracks in a flared slot lead top a ledge just below the top. Rap off from bolts or continue up a funky thin crack (5.8/9), the chimney just right (5.9) or walk off left.
content.protection: Standard rack to 2".

climbs.name: Fresno
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon & Kate Duke, December 1994

content.description: Fresno has crack and face climbing past 4 bolts. This climb has been around for while, but just missed being in Randy's original guide, so it has remained " a sleeper " for all these years.  It has have very few ascents.
content.protection: small to med. cams, and QDs for the 4 bolts .  I believe you need to set your own anchor.
content.location: Far left side of N. face of Snickers.

climbs.name: Don't Think Just Jump
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, October 1978

content.description:
Scamper up a short left-facing corner to a stance below a shallow, oblique corner which is stemmed to another small stance. From here make some thoughtful moves (5.10-) up and left to get established in the left of two slanting crack systems which ends at a ledge; at the crux shorter climbers are advised to take a hint from the name! Finish the route by climbing slightly left to join the upper half of Humerous, which has a few gear placements and two bolts and features fun climbing on incut edges up a steep face. Belay/rap from the Humerous anchors.

While easily overlooked this route should not be, as it presents the climber with an interesting variety of moves on mostly good rock. The route can be finished via the route

Funny Bone

but the newer finish up Humerous is much better, with less rope drag and more interesting moves. Two stars out of five.
content.protection: 2 bolts, gear to 2.5", bolted anchor/rap
content.location:
About 15 feet right of

Humerous

and almost directly behind a small scrub oak with a broken trunk is this fun route with complex and challenging moves.

climbs.name: Frankenwood
climbs.fa: unknown

content.description: The route starts with bouldery moves up a slightly right leaning dihedral. Pro looks a little awkward to place in the thin crack of the dihedral. Continue up easy scrambling moves to the base of a dike/lieback crack just left of a very easy finish. Lieback the crack past a crystal knob and a face move to the top. Easily TR'ed off the convenience anchor found at the top. Definitely worth climbing but maybe without the stress of being on lead!
content.protection: Standard rack to 2"

climbs.name: Crime of the Century
climbs.fa: Mike Waugh & Nick Badyrka, January 1978

content.description: Hard moves over a roof (the crux) to a strenuous handcrack lead to a ledge with rap anchor. The upper part is seldom done but continues up steep and varied crack climbing.
content.protection: Standard rack to 3"

climbs.name: Bakersfield
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon & Kate Duke, December 1994

content.description: This is the wide crack at the left end of the N. Face of Snickers. I believe it is the last established route on this side of the cliff. It's been around for awhile now, but has seen very few ascents.
content.protection: Wide pro.
content.location: Far left side of N. Face of Snickers
